'''Alain Desrosières''' (1940 – February 2013) was a statistician at the [[INSEE]] and a sociologist and historian of science at the [[EHESS]] ([[France]]), well known for his work in the history of [[statistics]].<ref>{{cite web | title = L'UQAM décerne un doctorat honorifique à Alain Desrosières dans le cadre du 25e anniversaire du CIRST | year = 2011 | publisher = Université du Québec à Montréal | url = http://www.nouvelles.uqam.ca/2011/luqam-decerne-un-doctorat-honorifique-alain-desrosieres-cadre-25e-anniversaire-cirst | accessdate = 16 February 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite document | title = Why statistics tend not only to describe the world but to change it | author = Lorraine Daston | issn = 0260-9592 | work = London Review of Books | volume = 22 | issue = 8 | year = 2000 | pages = 35–36 | url = http://www.lrb.co.uk/v22/n08/lorraine-daston/why-statistics-tend-not-only-to-describe-the-world-but-to-change-it}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|first1=Gilles|last1=Raveaud|title=Alain Desrosières est mort|date=15 February 2013|url=http://alternatives-economiques.fr/blogs/raveaud/2013/02/15/alain-desrosieres-est-mort/|work=Alternatives économiques|language=French}}</ref> He is the author of ''The Politics of Large Numbers: A History of Statistical Reasoning''.<ref>{{cite book |title=The politics of large numbers : a history of statistical reasoning |last1=Desrosières |first1=Alain |year=1998 |publisher=Harvard University Press |location=Cambridge, Mass |isbn=978-0-674-00969-1 |url=http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674009691 }}</ref>
